introduction_japanese: 敬語は、学校や会社での会話、店でのやりとりで使います。日常でも年上の人に話すときに出てきます。
introduction_english: けいご: used in school or work conversations, and at stores. It also comes up when talking to older people in daily life.
meaning_explanation_japanese: 目上の人に対して、ていねいに話すための表現。相手をうやまう気持ちを表すことばの形です。
meaning_explanation_english: It is used as a noun. けいご literally refers to honorifics in Japanese, the polite speech forms that show respect to the listener or a third person.
youtube_description: Learn what keigo means and how to use it naturally in real conversations. We cover honorifics, polite style, and easy examples you can start using today.

common_words: 敬礼（けいれい）: salute, bow
単語（たんご）: word, vocabulary item

kanji_explanation: The first kanji means respect and reverence. You see it in けいい, which is the feeling of esteem. It also appears in けいれい, a polite salute or bow. So it signals courteous attitude toward others. The second kanji means language, word, or speech. You see it in げんご for language in general. It also shows in たんご for a single word. So it points to words and how we speak.
synonyms: 丁寧語 : ていねいご : polite style
尊敬語 : そんけいご : honorific style
synonym_explanation: The most common synonyms of the word are ていねいご and そんけいご. They overlap with けいご because they are parts of the same system, but each names a specific subtype rather than the whole.
antonyms: ため口 : ためぐち : casual speech
普通体 : ふつうたい : plain style
antonym_explanation: The most common antonyms of the word are ためぐち and ふつうたい. They describe non-polite or plain styles, which contrast with けいご’s respectful, formal tone.
